data.title: Cinco de Mayo Fiesta, Beaverton family bike ride, Beethoven’s Ninth: 18 things to do this week
data.meta_description: Check out this list of events for May 5-11, 2023
data.text:
Seriously, if you’re not finding something fun to do this week, you’re not even trying. We’ve got a long list of entertainment options that range from the celebration of Cinco de Mayo to a farm fest in Yamhill County to several visual art shows. If you schedule it carefully, you can fill up your entire weekend with performances, and if you still have energy left, we’ve got a couple of fun events during the week.

Although the state-wide indoor COVID-19 mask mandate has lifted, some venues or artists still have restrictions in place. Check venue websites for information on specific COVID safety requirements.

Cinco de Mayo Fiesta

After several years off during the pandemic, the Portland Guadalajara Sister City Association and Treadway Events have again partnered to offer the Portland Cinco De Mayo Fiesta at Waterfront Park. “Our festival not only celebrates rich heritage and culture but also embodies community and inclusivity. We can’t wait to see everyone come together again to enjoy the food, music, and traditions that make this event so special,” said Brandon Treadway of Treadway Events. The bilingual event welcomes top performers including the internationally acclaimed Mariachi Ciudad de Guadalajara, direct from Guadalajara, Oregon’s very own Ballet Folklórico México en La Piel, and other live performances. Check here for a schedule of entertainment: cincodemayoportland.com/schedule. There will also be traditional foods, a family fun carnival, a naturalization ceremony, boxing and tequila tasting.

11 a.m.-11 p.m. Friday-Sunday, May 5-7, Waterfront Park, on Southwest Naito Parkway; admission $8-$10; advance online at aftontickets.com.

Rockwood Market Hall Cinco de Mayo

Of course, Waterfront Park won’t be the only venue hosting Cinco de Mayo celebrations. Rockwood Market Hall, an open-air market featuring micro-retail and restaurant spaces, welcomes the lively musical group Mariachi Guadalajara for live music and performances by Ballet Folklorico in celebration of the holiday. Shop local vendors, get your face painted and sample some tasty foods.

4-7 p.m. Friday, May 5, Rockwood Market Hall, 458 S.E. 185th Ave.; free admission; rockwoodmarkethall.com/events.

Multnomah Arts Center Spring Arts and Crafts Sale

Spring is certainly the season for arts and craft sales. If you’re in the Multnomah Village area, here’s a show in your neighborhood featuring the work of at least 40 artists in ceramics, textiles, jewelry, prints, paint, woodworking, and other media. Proceeds benefit the artist and support future programming at the arts center.

9 a.m.-9 p.m. Friday, 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, May 5-6, Multnomah Arts Center, 7688 S.W. Capitol Highway; free admission; MultnomahArtsCenter.org.

“The Play You Want”

The gritty comedy written by Bernardo Cubría explores the divide between exploitation and acceptance. While wrestling with the theatre world’s desires to box him in, the Mexican playwright sarcastically pitches “Nar-Cocos,” a play about drug dealers on Día de los Muertos. Much to his surprise, the theater picks it up. With possible success in his future, he must decide just how much he’s willing to compromise in order to finally be accepted.

Opens 7:30 p.m. Friday, May 5 and continues 7:30 p.m. Thursdays-Saturdays, 2 p.m. Sundays through May 20, Milagro Theatre, 525 S.E. Stark St.; tickets $20-$27; app.arts-people.com.

Garcia Birthday Band

The Portland-based Grateful Dead cover band offers a Cinco de Mayo show that uses the Dead’s repertoire as a springboard for limitless potential and plenty of improvisation. Expect the unexpected. The show is partially-seated, so there will be room for dancing.

8 p.m. Friday, May 5, Alberta Rose Theater, 3000 N.E. Alberta St.; tickets $20; event.etix.com/ticket.

“Americana, Wide Open Spaces”

The Westside Community & Youth Orchestra offers its spring 2023 concert built around Aaron Copeland’s music. The program also includes three pieces from the “Billy the Kid ballet,” along with three pieces by other American composers, including Bruce Broughton, Mark O’Connor and John Keltonic.

7:30 p.m. Friday, May 5, First Congregational Church United Church of Christ, 494 E. Main St., Hillsboro. The concert repeats May 12 at Liberty High School; admission is free, donations accepted; wcyo.org.

Beach, Bike & Blues Festival (Waldport)

Head to the Oregon coast this weekend for a 6-hour festival of blues music (including performances by Sonny Hess, Lisa Mann and Kelly Pierce) that also offers a craft and vendor fair, beer garden and more than 800 bike racers and their guests who are participating in the annual Oregon Coast Gravel Epic in Waldport.

Noon-7 p.m. Saturday, May 6, Alsea Bay Bridge Visitor Center and Museum, on U.S. 101 at the south end of the bridge, Waldport; free; findyourselfinwaldport.com.

Yamhill County Farm Fest

The Yamhill Valley Heritage Center presents its annual festival and plowing competition. Learn about historic farming methods and watch as more than 20 teams of draft horses and mules do their work. Live demonstrations, horse-drawn and antique equipment displays, pioneer kids’ activities, tours of the museum and 1880′s Hutchcroft School, old-time music, and food for purchase.

10 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, May 6, Yamhill Valley Heritage Center, 11275 S.W. Durham Lane, McMinnville; admission $8, 12 and younger free; details 503-472-2842.

Spring Garden Fair (Canby)

Spring is in the air in Clackamas County when the garden fair fills the fairgrounds with plant and tool vendors, Ask a Master Gardener booths, a raffle, children’s activities, new plant introduction talks, and even soil testing (which is way more important than most people know). Get inspired.

9 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturday, 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Sunday, May 6-7, Clackamas County Fairgrounds & Event Center, 694 N.E. Fourth Ave., Canby; $5; springgardenfair.org.

Best Day Family Bike Ride

The Beaverton Downtown Association is offering a free bicycle ride guided by safety leaders and the Beaverton Police Department. The short ride is 1.5 miles through downtown Beaverton and great for families. There’s an after party with activities for kids, free cookies, and a raffle. The ride highlights the new Beaverton bike racks and repair stations that offer basic tools and built-in tire pumps. Get tips on bike maintenance and repair just in time for the kickoff of pleasure biking season.

Noon Saturday, May 6 kicking off at Beaverton City Park, 12500 S.W. Fourth St., Beaverton; free registration here: eventbrite.com/e/best-day-of-the-year-family-bike-ride.

Bubble & Squeeze

Jet Black Pearl and The Amazing Bubble Man offer up a different sort of entertainment when they take the stage to create amazing bubble art, and amazing accordion music. Normally we think of bubble shows as family entertainment, and The Bubble Man does plenty of those sorts of shows, but this show is for the big kids (ages 16 and older) with a more free-flowing descriptive narrative about the mind-bending and “sometimes sexy” nature of his creations. Jet Black Pearl gets to sing her songs that aren’t for young ears. And everyone over 21 gets to have a drink while enjoying the show.

7 p.m. Saturday, May 6, Clinton Street Theater, 2522 S.E. Clinton St.; tickets $15; cstpdx.com/event/bubble-squeeze/.

“Visions & Voyages”

Cascadia Composers highlight the work of Carla K. Bartlett, Adam Eason, Brian T. Field, Zhengtao Pan, Paul Safar, Dawn Lenore Sonntag, and others in a concert of new music. Livestreaming option available.

7:30 p.m. Saturday, May 6, Lincoln Hall, PSU Campus, 1620 S.W. Park Ave.; $20; visionsandvoyages.brownpapertickets.com.

Kodomo no Hi, Children’s Day at Portland Japanese Garden

Kodomo no Hi, also called Children’s Day, is commemorated each year in Japan on May 5 to celebrate the growth and good fortune of children. The Portland Japanese Garden will hold its celebration later in the weekend and offer a range of family-friendly activities including a taiko performances, origami koi or frogs art project, a treasure hunt, and displays of koi nobori, or cloth carp streamers. Free with garden admission.

10:30 a.m.-3:30 p.m. Sunday, May 7, Portland Japanese Garden, 611 S.W. Kingston Ave.; admission $15.95-$21.95; japanesegarden.org/events.

Portland Youth Philharmonic plays Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony

For the first time in its 99-year history, the Portland Youth Philharmonic will perform Ludwig van Beethoven’s remarkable Ninth Symphony. PYP will be joined by the Portland Symphonic Choir and vocal soloists Vanessa Isiguen, Hannah Penn, Anthony Kalil, and Zachary Lenox.

4 p.m. Sunday, May 7, Arlene Schnitzer Concert Hall, 1037 S.W. Broadway; tickets $15-$65; portlandyouthphil.org/concerts.

“La Passione”

Vancouver Symphony Orchestra USA’s 10th anniversary chamber music series continues with “La Passione,” a program featuring soloists Angelika Furtwangler, viola, and Alan Juza, oboe, along with the full VSO Chamber Orchestra. Igor Shakhman conducts a program of the works of Haydn, Telemann, Chevalier de Saint-Georges, and Albinoni.

3 p.m. Sunday, May 7, Royal Durst Theater, 3101 Main St., Vancouver; tickets $25; vancouversymphony.org.

Soul Queens & Blues Kings “Making It Real Concert”

This special showcase of area soul and blues icons is a benefit for Health Care For All Oregon. Performers include Norman “Boogie Cat” Sylvester, LaRhonda Steele, Myrtle Brown, Sarah Billings and many others who will pay tribute to the greats including Aretha Franklin, Gladys Knight, Etta James, and Muddy Waters.

4:30 p.m. Sunday, May 7, Aladdin Theatre, 3017 S.E. Milwaukie Ave.; tickets $25 advance, $30 at door; event.etix.com.

Society of Washington Artists Annual Spring Art Show

We’ve got another art show celebrating spring in southwest Washington this week. Local artist show works from traditional oil paintings to contemporary mixed media to 3D sculpture. In a unique twist, this show offers weekday viewing, as well as weekend hours, to give visitors plenty of time and space to look over the works presented.

Show hours: 2-7 p.m. Tuesday, May 9, noon-7 p.m. Wednesday-Friday, May 10-12 and 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, May 13, Vancouver United Church of Christ, 1220 N.E. 68th St.; Vancouver; free admission; swavancouver.com.

“Bad Friends” with Andrew Santino and Bobby Lee

Comedians Andrew Santino and Bobby Lee fresh off their hit podcast “Bad Friends” are touring this spring and make a stop in Portland. The podcast showcases the dynamic and sometimes “contentious” relationship between Lee and Santino, providing audiences with backstage glimpse into their world. What kind of topics will they bring up? The sky’s the limit but expect plenty of f-bombs.

7:30 p.m. Thursday, May 11, Arlene Schnitzer Concert Hall, 1037 S.W. Broadway; tickets start at $39.50; portland5.com.

- If you have events you’d like to see highlighted at OregonLive.com or in the weekly printed A&E section of The Oregonian, please email submissions to events@oregonian.com at least three weeks prior to the start of your event. Digital images or links to videos are helpful.

— Rosemarie Stein

503-221-4376, events@oregonian.com; @trafficportland
